messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hello: Blade ID Mei att..
messages.msgSnippet: Hello: The more I look at it the more it looks like a non-Japanese origin sword that was passed off as what it isn t..the lack of a Yokote, along with a couple
messages.messageBody:
Hello:

The more I look at it the more it looks like a non-Japanese origin sword
that was passed off as what it isn't..the lack of a Yokote, along with a
couple of other things bug me..I paid a whopping $20.00 for this and well, it's
worth that to me as a "What NOT to buy" example for my Iai and Batto
students, still it has a decent Hamon on it... I had a good idea it wasn't an
original..I basically took it cause it does have a nice Hamon.

Now the ones that I am finishing up making for book IV will in no way ever
be confused with ANYTHING original simply by the way I am signing them and
the method of polish...You can get a really NICE polish ("working" type)
just by using wet/dry paper up to 2500 grit wet and then hit it with 5000
pumice in an oil suspension. NOT for real swords but for "modern Japan-ish"
stuff that I am making for cutting up mats and the like...shows nice
structures within the blade as well as the Hada on the laminated ones..

I will just stash this one away for the above purposes....

Thanks all

JPH

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hello: Blade ID Mei att..
messages.msgSnippet: Jim - We need better photos of the entire blade, the entire nakago and then maybe better close-ups of the mei. Based on what I can see; 石光信光 作　 it
messages.messageBody:
Jim -
We need better photos of the entire blade, the entire nakago and then
maybe better close-ups of the mei. Based on what I can see; 石光信光
作　 it looks like a mei but the spacing and such is awful funky, the
conclusion that this is a fake is a natural one given what we can see...
-t
Tom Helm
www.toryu-mon.com
"Moriamur, et in media arma ruamus"
- Vergil

> Consulate. He was a very pleasant man who had been collecting 3
> years and had 25 swords. They were all Chinese repros. Every last
> Mother of all Fakes one of them. Not a real Japanese blade there.
> Having said that, there were a very few that were worthy of the
> generic name "sword" as they actually looked good. They had hamon
> and hada and a passable sugata. But they were not Nihonto.
>
> Jim, I'll still bet on the basis of your one photo that your cheap
> estate pickup is a recent Chinese crapper. It is a hard call without
> the blade in hand, but here's looking forward to being found wrong...
>
> Bestests,
> BaZZa.
> aka Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hello: Blade ID Mei att..
messages.msgSnippet: Well, I once went to see a collection of Japanese swords at the request of a man who got my name and phone number from the Japanese Consulate.  He was a very
messages.messageBody:
Well, I once went to see a collection of Japanese swords at the request of a man who got my name and phone number from the Japanese Consulate. He was a very pleasant man who had been collecting 3 years and had 25 swords. They were all Chinese repros. Every last Mother of all Fakes one of them. Not a real Japanese blade there. Having said that, there were a very few that were worthy of the generic name "sword" as they actually looked good. They had hamon and hada and a passable sugata. But they were not Nihonto.

Jim, I'll still bet on the basis of your one photo that your cheap estate pickup is a recent Chinese crapper. It is a hard call without the blade in hand, but here's looking forward to being found wrong...

Bestests,
BaZZa.
aka Barry Thomas.

From: atarbaktar@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, August 08, 2012 2:58 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hello: Blade ID Mei att..



I dunno about Chinese repro...shows a decent Hamon...could be a old
forgery?

In a message dated 8/7/2012 10:28:25 A.M. Pacific Daylight Time,
atarbaktar@... writes:

Hello:

I just picked this up at an estate sale..all it is really is the blade and
a ratty leather covered siya.. no habaki, just a blade and the siya with
one suspension ring. Supposedly a WWII bring back by a US Marine..the
folks
said that the rest of the fittings were "around somewhere"...too bad cause
they are probably worth more than this blade is but...

Hope the attachment comes through..

No "damage" to the blade, mei is somewhat clear, rubbed flour into it for
contrast. No imperial mum or star chops..anyone have an idea who this is?
Didn't pay much for it...not much at all...

well back to the forges for me.

THANK YOU all!!

JPH

Dr JP Hrisoulas, COL NANG (Ret)
Bladesmith.
